moves.1. e4 e5 2. Qh5: Patzer opening.  Black usually does well with Nc6 here.
moves.2... Qe7: This too is ok, provided white doesn't play Bc4.
moves.3. Nc3 g6 4. Qf3 h5 5. Bc4: I kind of like Nd5 here, which threatens the black queen.  Black must then play Qd6 or Qc5 to defend against NxPc7+ which forks black's a rook.
moves.5... Nf6 6. Nh3 Qc5: Nothing is defending against QxNf6.  Black must then protect the h rook, perhaps with Rh7 to protect against QxPf7+.  This gives white ample time to reposition the white bishop to safety, or defend it.
moves.7. d3: The free knight looked a lot better to me.
moves.7... Ke7 8. Ng5 d5: White has three (four counting the queen) pieces on d5, black only two.
moves.9. Nxd5+: I think I like 9. BxPd5 better.  NxN, 10. BxN, QxPc2 11. Qf6+ lets white pick up black's h rook.
moves.9... Nxd5 10. exd5 Bg4 11. Qg3: I prefer QxPf7+.  Black's choices are Kd8, in which case 12 Ne6+ picks off the black queen, or Kd6 which drives the black king into the battlefield.  Actually, Kd6 results with Ne4+ and again the black queen falls into darkness, trampled beneath the white knight's hooves.
moves.11... Qd4 12. c3 h4 13. cxd4 hxg3 14. dx: Bg4 is worth more than Pc7.  BxNe6 would have defended against NxPc7.
moves.17. fxg4 fxe5 18. Bg5+ Kd7 19. Bxa6 Bb4+: ?  I would have moved Pa6 or Pa5.  Rh7 permits NxBf8 for free.
moves.26. Nxf8: Actually, not for free.  I overlooked Rf7+.
moves.26... Rf7+: Here we expect Kg3, RnNf8, RxPh2.
